question: How can I go?
answer: Put on your wash-and-wear suit and your clip-on tie, have your landlady tie your shoes for you, and show up at the church. Simple. Me and Carol are going.

question: What?
answer: Hey, look -- we've known Kristin since... since she was conceived in that cabin up in Big Bear. Remember? You and Edie banged the wall so hard, me and Carol were picking plaster out of our hair for a week...

question: Goddammit, Tug -- I want to see Kristin get married, okay? But--
answer: But you're bummed because your ex and her new husband are paying for the whole thing.

question: Shit, if Kristin had to get married where I could afford it, we'd be holding the reception at Buddy's Burgers. Uh-oh... Check it out. Does that look at all suspicious to you?
answer: Whatever gave you that idea? This is one-Henry-seven, we've got a possible two-eleven in progress at Porter's Mini-Mart, corner of Court and Alvarado. Requesting backup.

question: Let's do it, partner. You got your vest?
answer: Of course. Right in the trunk of the car.

question: Yeah, that's comforting. Mine, too.
answer: Watch the driver. I'm going for a better angle on the door.

question: I got him. Don't get pinned. Aw, shit. Get outta there!
answer: I can't! Do you mind!

question: I'll cover you! Get outta there!!
answer: Move it!

question: I am all right. Your hand will require attention.
answer: Get the hell away from me! I don't need your goddamn help.

question: An identical round was used in the shooting of a Newcomer named Hubley, two days ago. Perhaps because even the larger caliber handguns aren't always effective against my people.
answer: You saying there's some connection to this other homicide?

question: Excuse me.
answer: So, you think there's a connection, or what? Hey! So what've you got on Tuggle's killers?

question: So, you think there's a connection, or what? Hey! So what've you got on Tuggle's killers?
answer: Jesus, Sykes -- it's been less than ten hours. Me and Alterez are on it, okay?

question: You don't have squat.
answer: You ever try to make a case in Slagtown? The list of Newcomer informants is about as long as the list of Mexican war heroes... ... Nobody talks to nobody down there. Half of them don't speak English and the other half only when it suits them. It's gonna take some time.

question: Good.
answer: There's another case I'd like to take. A homicide -- a Newcomer named Hubley.

question: Granger and Pitts are already on it.
answer: Granger and Pitts have one hell of a caseload... and I would have thought with Jetson here being the first Newcomer plainclothes, and Hubley's body being found over in the Newcomer community...

question: Don't tell me what to think.
answer: ... and we work my hours. I'll do the driving, you do the paperwork. You gotta learn it so you might as well do it all.

question: ... and we work my hours. I'll do the driving, you do the paperwork. You gotta learn it so you might as well do it all.
answer: Sergeant... I'd like to thank you for what you're doing.

question: What's that? Look, Jetson. Get this straight in your head. We're not pals, we're not married, and we ain't gonna take long moonlight walks together... We're just partners. And don't call me Sergeant. Call me Sykes... or Matt if you have to.
answer: I am George.

question: Wait a minute. George? George Jetson? Man, somebody really hung one on you! I've heard some good ones for you guys... Humphrey Bogart, Harley Davidson. I guess the people at immigration got a little punchy after a while, coming up with names for a quarter of a million of you. You weren't at the back of the line, were you, George?
answer: My true name is Ss'tangya T'ssorentsa'.

question: Gesundheit. You don't mind if I stick to George, do you? Anyway, what's it matter to you if we think it's funny, right? Whatta you care?
answer: That is exactly so. It is like your name... Sykes. I'm sure it doesn't bother you at all that it sounds like "ss'ai k'ss", two words in my language which mean "excrement" and "cranium". "Shit... head".

question: Let's talk Hubley.
answer: His body was discovered three days ago, in an alley off of Central Avenue, near downtown.

question: With two BRI Sabot slugs in the chest.
answer: Through the chest. Rupturing both the primary and secondary hearts.

question: Nice signal, dickwad!
answer: He was employed at the Northwest Petroleum Refinery in Torrance. He was manager of the Methane Facility. He was also a principle partner in a real estate venture to develop low- cost housing for Newcomers.

question: Terrific. A real pillar of the community. Was Hubley missing anything when they found him? Was he ripped off?
answer: There was no wallet... but he was still wearing a watch and two rings.

question: The guys at the mini-mart last night made a half-assed stab at the money in the till -- but I don't think that's what they were there for. I think we got us a couple'a executions on our hands, George...
answer: The murder at the mini-mart is not our case. The Captain said--

question: Look, you want to fit in here, right? You want to learn how to get along?
answer: Yes.

question: Well, there's a thing about partners, about being somebody's partner. You do for each other. And other people's rules don't mean shit. It's the rules set up between the two of you, that's all that counts. Understand? Okay. Well, my friend and partner was shot last night and I'm after the shitbag that did it. As my partner, I'm asking you to respect me and help me find him.
answer: And as my partner, I ask you to respect me and my desire not to break with procedure. What is wrong?

question: Nothing's wrong. I just want to get something straight. You agree that there's a good chance these two shootings are somehow related, right?
answer: Well... yes, quite possibly.

question: Possibly. Good. Well, would you be willing to accept the theory, George, that... possibly... by examining the evidence from one case we might shed some small ray of light on the other? Does that sound unreasonable to you?
answer: Yes... no, it is not unreasonable. Although I--

question: Great. Well, I'm sure glad that's settled, aren't you? I think we're really starting to click now, George -- hmmm?
answer: You know I've been over all this with Fedorchuk and Alterez this morning...

question: Come on. You got nothin' better to do, cushy county job like yours.
answer: Yeah, right. Don't push your luck. Anyway, according to the sheet, the guy you nailed outside by the car--

question: The human?
answer: Yeah... he was one Martin Helder. White male, twenty-seven. Let's see... wrap sheet shows one armed robbery conviction, a couple for sale of a controlled substance. Oh yeah, and he was wired on coke when you stopped his clock.

question: So far he's a John Doe. Or a Sam Slag, if you like. No I.D. on him and -- well, you know, no fingerprints -- so it could be tough. Your buddies this morning went through the mug book but couldn't make a facial match.
answer: Fedorchuk couldn't find his ass with his hands in his back pockets.

question: You took this gut out, too, didn't you?
answer: Yeah.

question: Lucky for you, you got him in both of his... well, what we loosely refer to as... hearts.
answer: Lucky nothing. I had to empty my damn gun into him.

question: That's the way these people are. You don't hit both pumps you just piss them off. Oh, here's an extra headshot if you need one. We're just about to start cutting in. You're welcome to stick around if you want. It's really fascinating stuff.
answer: Yeah, I'll bet. What's this? What's going on?

question: Yeah, I'll bet. What's this? What's going on?
answer: Nothing.

question: Nothing?
answer: Shouldn't we examine their personal effects? What is this?

question: A rubber. A condom. You know... Coney Island whitefish? Men, human men, put them on their, uh -- penises -- to protect against having babies. You need this for anything? Get the picture?
answer: And that fits?

question: Well... Yeah, it's rubber. It stretches.
answer: And still it fits?

question: What is this stuff?
answer: It is a resin. Newcomers working near methane gasses at oil refineries must paint it on their boots to protect against sparks.

question: How the hell do you know that?
answer: A large number of my people were hired by refineries because the methane fumes are not harmful to us. My spouse's brother is one.

question: So the Slag they're cutting into upstairs worked at a refinery just like Hubley worked at a refinery. I'd say that "possible" connection between the two cases just got a hell of a lot more possible. Okay, next step -- I gotta go talk to the wife of the Slag store owner blown away last night.
answer: I believe I should interview the widow alone.

question: Why the hell--?! Great, fine. You talk to the wife.
answer: Mr. Hubley was an all right guy -- and a damn good manager. The men liked him. I'm really gonna have to scramble to fill his shoes.

question: Well, one of the men didn't like him so much...
answer: You think this is the guy who did it?

question: We think he could'a been involved, yeah. You know him?
answer: To be honest, it's hard to say. I hate to admit it but -- they all still kinda look alike to me.

question: Who else can I ask around here?
answer: Wait. You know who it looks like? Yeah. Anderson. Uh... James Anderson. He isn't in today. He took the afternoon off.

question: I think you're gonna find he's taken the rest of his life off. That where Anderson worked?
answer: Yes it is. Thirty-five percent pure Methane gas in there. I don't know how these fellas do it.

question: Mrs. Porter is not taking her husband's death well.
answer: Did you learn anything?

question: A week ago two men came to see her husband. After they left, he was very frightened. She identified one of the men from a photo I showed her. It was Hubley.
answer: Aw-right. What about the other guy?

question: She didn't know him. But she said her son might.
answer: Did you talk to him?

question: Thank you all for that very warm reception. I'm particularly grateful because I actually had the gall to write that in my notes
answer: William Harcourt?

question: Yes...
answer: I'm Sergeant Sykes, and this is Detective Jetson, Los Angeles Police Department.

question: That's right. He and I, along with seven or eight others. Listen, gentlemen, I will be happy to assist you in any way I can -- unfortunately, at the moment, I'm overdue at another function.
answer: William...

question: Mr. Mayor...
answer: William, I was wondering if you wouldn't rather ride with Luisa and me. Two limousines trying to make it across town in all this traffic, we're bound to be later than we already are.

question: Excellent idea. Ray, I wonder if you know two of your police officers... Detective Jetson and Sykes.
answer: A pleasure. We really should be going.

question: Please feel free to call my office Monday morning for an appointment. Congratulations again on your promotion, Detective. Remember... you're out there setting an example in our community. I'll be keeping an eye on you.
answer: That cop, the human, he was the one who killed Anderson and the driver.

question: This is becoming a serious breach of security.
answer: He didn't recognize me.

question: Go on ahead. I'll be right in. What'd you dig up for me? What is it? Only holds five. No... two. Well, let's see what you got, Cochise. Gimme six, rapid fire. How long you been shooting? That's pitiful. Whattya gonna do if somebody draws down on you, wave your scores on the written exam at 'em?
answer: Why did you do it?

question: Why'd I do what?
answer: Agree to work with me? You don't like me... you don't like any of us. You have nothing but contempt for us. And yet you become an outcast from your club of detectives by making me your partner...

question: My partner is dead! Because one of you bastards killed him -- then disappeared into a rathole down in Slagtown, where he's home and dry, 'cause nobody sees nothing, nobody says nothing... But he didn't figure on you, George. You're going to get me through that wall of silence. You're going to make them talk to me. You're going to help me find that Slag son-of-a- bitch. Comprendo? And if Fedorchuk and the boys in the bullpen don't like it, screw them... and if the Captain doesn't like it, screw him... and if all the Slags down in Slagtown don't like it... well screw them too! Okay, just stay back and do what I do. Watch and learn, watch and learn... I can't see dick in here. Which one'a you Slags is Porter? Who said that?
answer: At the end of the bar.

question: You Porter?
answer: No, Matthew. I believe this is the one you want.

question: Your name wouldn't happen to be Porter, would it?
answer: Uh, Matthew...

question: Back off, George.
answer: But I-- .

question: You don't want to know.
answer: Tell me.

question: Your mother mates out of season.
answer: That's very colorful. But see -- now I've got a problem. I don't seem to be getting much cooperation from you, Porter. So I guess we're gonna have to take this little session down to my office, ya know?

question: Matthew, you don't have to-- .
answer: Stay back! I'm okay.

question: I told you -- I was in the back of the store. I just heard voices, muffled like.
answer: One of the two men was Hubley, right? What about the other one? Did you know him?

question: Yeah... I seen him around. High- roller dude named Strader. Joshua Strader. Runs a club on the west side. Encounters.
answer: Yeah, I heard of it.

question: Oh, God. I think I got yours here... Which one is that? Raw what?
answer: This is mole. It's good.

question: I'll bet. Would it really put you out if they tossed that on the grill for a minute or two?
answer: Our bodies do not assimilate the nutrients if the food has been cooked.

question: Oh, that's real attractive. You got fur in your teeth, George. Come on, man, we're gonna be talking to people... jeez. So what was that other word for Human... Slow ka?
answer: Ss'loka'. It means literally "small but intelligent creature". It loses much in the translation.

question: And what was that one about my mother? That was a good one.
answer: Ss'trokya ss'lato 'na'.

question: Yeah, that's it. Say it slow.
answer: You are Cassandra?

question: She did, did she? Well, she was wrong. Excuse me, I have to change.
answer: No problem. Look, we're not here doing an interview for the school paper. This is a homicide investigation... and if you don't stop jerkin' us around, I'm ready to start playin' hardball.

question: Oooh. Hardball. That sounds interesting. Are you going to strike me? You could tie me up and then do whatever you want with me... I've got my own ropes.
answer: Does that cost extra or you throw them in?

question: Look, I don't know where Mr. Strader might be. He comes and he goes.
answer: The girl out front mentioned Strader's assistant, somebody named Watson. Maybe he knows.

question: Todd? Todd doesn't know either. I know... Why don't you hang around for a while, let me entertain you? It's Matt, right? Now tell me the truth, have you ever... made it... with one of us?
answer: Not unless I got real drunk and nobody told me about it later.

question: A virgin. I find that very arousing...
answer: There's lots of things I haven't done, but his ain't high on the list. Don't take it personally.

question: I think you're just a little scared now, about what you might find once the lights go out. A little scared... and a lot curious. Maybe more than you want to admit. But doesn't that turn you on, that curiosity and fear, swirling together? Think of it as broadening your horizons.
answer: I like my horizons narrow.

question: Your voice is saying no, but your body is saying yes.
answer: My voice, body, and everything else is saying I'll be back in two hours for Strader, and he better damn well be here.

question: My arm's gettin' tired and so far, zip.
answer: He is ss'verdlatya ss'alo to Strader.

question: What's that mean?
answer: Duty-bonded. His allegiance to Strader is above pain or life.

question: You tellin' me this guy would die before he'd screw his boss and work for us? Nobody's that dumb.
answer: It is something you couldn't comprehend, Quint.

question: Would you mind?
answer: So, she keeps you on a pretty short leash, does she?

question: My wife? She worries about me.
answer: Yeah... I know the routine.

question: You are married?
answer: Was. Divorced.

question: We mate for life. Divorce... is a strange concept to us.
answer: It's like having an eleventh finger removed. It hurts like hell, but you never really needed the damn thing in the first place.

question: Your home is quite disordered. I thought perhaps you had been burglarized when I walked in.
answer: I appreciate your honesty, George. Ignore the bitch on the left, that's Edie. I call her Edi Amin... This is Kristin, my daughter. It's kinda an old picture... she's twenty now. Getting married, in fact... on Sunday.

question: Human children can be very beautiful. Getting married? Congratulations. You will be taking Sunday off, then...
answer: Maybe not... I don't know. I'm not sure I'm gonna go. She doesn't need her burn-out of a father there...

question: I must show you... And this is Richard. My son. He's four years old. We named him after the former President, Richard Nixon.
answer: You open to a piece of advice? Tell people you named him after Richard Burton, the actor. Just take my word for it. ... and so, and so the doctor says, "If this is the thermometer, then where'd I leave the pen?" You're not... you don't think that's funny? George, work with me, I always get a laugh with that one. Look, if the doctor's got the thermometer in his hand, then where's his pen gotta be?

question: In the other man's rectum.
answer: Sticking out of his ass... yeah! See, that's what makes it a joke. There's like a surprise, and your mind fills in the funny picture. Here's this guy with a pen stuck in his ass and he thinks it's a thermometer. Nada, huh? Your health...

question: Ta ss'trakyona'... There is so much our two peoples don't understand about each other.
answer: No shit, Holmes. You're only from another goddamn planet, for chrissakes.

question: You humans are very curious to us. You invite us to live among you, in an atmosphere of equality we've never known before. You lay before us a beautiful green world, full of freedoms and opportunities... You give us ownership of our lives for the first time... and you ask no more of us than you do of yourselves I hope you can understand how special your world is... how unique a people you humans are. So it us all the more painful and confusing to us that so few of you seem capable of living up the the ideals you set for yourselves.
answer: Don't count on me, George. I never had any ideals.

question: We don't understand the hatred, the contempt. But we must bear it... we must not react in anger... because our situation here is still fragile. The separationists would see us returned to the quarantine camps. The fundamentalists say we have no more human rights than dogs or cats. But the prejudice we face here is so insignificant compared to the pain that we've known before. And that is why we are so grateful.
answer: Yeah, well... except I did hear you eat your dead.

question: Only on Fridays.
answer: You son-of-a-bitch. You're okay.

question: I'm going home.
answer: Yeah, go home. Get some sleep. You do sleep, don't you? What a wildman... This better be good news or money.

question: Hold this. I feel very terrible.
answer: Where'd you get this?!!

question: A man, a human, was wiring it to your car. I didn't get a good look at him. I must call my wife... She's going to divorce me.
answer: George, she's not gonna divorce you. You mate for life, remember?

question: She's very progressive. I'm certain she's considering it.
answer: Yeah. Well, let's roll, George.

question: To the... to the beach?
answer: Come on, let's go, dude. Surf's up!

question: Stop the car.
answer: Why?

question: Please, I must get out here.
answer: Come on, you won't have to get near the water.

question: Stop the car!
answer: All right, okay. Keep your pantyhose on. Jeez, when in doubt, freak out, for chrissake. It's all right, George. It's cool. Just wait here, all right? I'll be back in a coupla minutes.

question: Found his wallet in his jacket pocket. Joshua Strader, big as life.
answer: How're you two doing on Tuggle's killer? Yeah, that's real good. You guys follow up on that for a coupla months.

question: Look at your dildo partner. He's too scared to even come down to the sand. You're not gonna get wet standing here, moron!
answer: I'd like to see you next to a sea of hydrochloric acid, Fedorchuk... see how much surfin' you'd do. Cute.

question: Well, if it isn't Detective Jetson. Forget you hip waders, big guy?
answer: Lay off, asshole.

question: I may be an asshole, but at least I'm a real detective, not some outer shit space thing.
answer: Yeah? you're a real honest-to-god detective...? Then detect these!

question: Yeah? you're a real honest-to-god detective...? Then detect these!
answer: What was that about?

question: Nothing. ... So we've got three guys dead. All Newcomers, all killed the same way -- execution style.
answer: Warren Hubley was in middle management at a refinery... Joshua Strader operated a successful bar and nightclub...

question: Did he find anything? Well?
answer: It is nothing.

question: What's this nothing shit? It wasn't nothing yesterday when you asked Bentner to run that test and he looked like he was about to shit peach pits, and it's not nothing now. Don't lie to me, George, you're bad at it.
answer: You must leave me alone on this.

question: No, see, I don't leave you alone... I'm your partner. I don't work that way... Tug didn't work that way. No secrets, goddammit! You don't hold back from me. Whatever is going on, you're gonna tell me now!
answer: No. I cannot involve you. This is not your concern.

question: The hell it isn't, when somebody wires up enough C-4 explosive to my car to turn me into pink mist! That Slag was on something, and not sour milk, either? Am I right? TELL ME! What is it?
answer: ... It is called ss'jabroka'. To us it is a potent narcotic.

question: How potent?
answer: Like your cocaine, I suppose. The "high" lasts several hours. We would receive small amounts of it... as a reward for our labor.

question: We? You've taken it?
answer: We all did.

question: Where did he get it? Was there any of it on the ship?
answer: No... I am sure not. That is why I am so concerned... someone must now be producing it here. But none of my people know how to make it. The process was carefully guarded.

question: Jesus, this is major. Why didn't you tell me sooner? Why'd you hold out on me?
answer: Your people don't know about this part of out past. And they can't know -- It would threaten our entire existence here.

question: George... look me in the eye... George, you don't ever lie to me again.
answer: I must trust you, Matthew. I cannot stop this without you.

question: ... They took the stuff out, all of it -- this afternoon.
answer: How much?

question: About fifty kilos... of concentrate... and some street grade... in tubes.
answer: Where have they taken it?

question: George, c'mon -- lighten up. It's a beauty of a case. Don't sweat it -- we got him by the short hairs. He ain't gonna make any more of the shit.
answer: The fifty kilos, Matthew. I have to find it. I can't let it get out on the street.

question: Why? What's the big goddamn deal? (continuing; as Jetson starts the car You destroy that drug, you destroy the case. Don't blow the whole thing now by not following procedure.
answer: Fuck procedure.

question: It'd be for your own good. I think you'd be better off with a partner who's a little more... by the book. ... Still, I gotta tell you, George, for a quiet guy, you're sure hell on wheels once you get going. I'd kinda hate to miss your next two days as a detective.
answer: I'll give you guys a lift to the station. They're waiting to take your statements on the shootings.

question: Let's go, partner. And it's shooting. Singular.
answer: They said two.

question: Wiltey, no.
answer: What is this?!

question: ... It's Harcourt.
answer: Harcourt is dead.

question: No he's not. Not if he overdosed on the drug. Massive amounts trigger a... a change. Your body functions seize up, you appear to be dead, but it's really a state of incubation. When you emerge you're...
answer: Tell me about it... I never thought I'd say this, but -- for once in my life I think I'm willing to wait for back-up.

question: We can't let him get away.
answer: Why the hell are you so dead set against back-up?

question: Because... because of what will happen if humans see what we are capable of becoming.
answer: But there's no more drug.
